The IT division is a patchwork of teams with different work habits, culture and technology. 

One can usually expect a good work environment, modern(ish) technology, challenging problems, plenty of learning opportunities - especially if joins the right team. Make sure to learn about the specific team you are about to join to.

Think twice before accepting an offer of a contractor role. While treated equally to employees in usual workplace matters, contractors are not entitled to bonuses, more difficult / less likely to get a raise and cannot get promoted. Conversion of contractors to full time employees do happen, but there are no guarantees and chances are different from team to team.

If you are a mid career professional, make sure to join at the compensation and organization level you really want to be. Getting ahead within in the organization will be much more difficult. Do you want to be promoted to a VP or ED from within? Think about embarking on the campaign trail for president.

An interesting pattern however, that some contractors might get converted directly into a VP role if they happen to be the last senior member of a team hit by turnover. This hurts the morale.

review_title: Financial Advisor Associate or Rat Race Telemarketer?
pros:
Generous initial base pay, benefits included personal life insurance, and state-of-art facilities. 

Networking opportunities within firm departments, other banks, insurance companies, mutual fund companies, third-party market researchers, and insitutional asset managers.
cons:
Stalemate office environment. Senior management depreciates lower level employees. Highly political. Very little structure led to lots of wasted time, boredom, and late night cold calling. 

The pay grid discourages mid-senior level advisors transfer AUM to new hires because MS pays new hires a higher grid rate.  It's part of the program. In your first year, you get paid a higher rate than your third year.  That's right. You initially make more in base pay + rate of commission, compared to, say fifth year.  It's a downward pay rate slope.  Because it's understood that you should have a larger AUM as time goes on. It's designed to pay upfront in first year, then decreases significantly.  By the end of the third year, you're expected to live off AUM entirely. But the capital raising goals don't stop after you graduate the program. And they will cut your pay grid to about 35% after you hit a certain AUM.

review_title: Very hierarchical (focused on job titles) with pockets of excellence (e.g. Technology Investment Banking).
pros: One advantage of working there was the quality of the people. Since it's difficult to get into Morgan Stanley, you'll work with very smart people. Benefits are good, but pay is only good if you work in a revenue-focused role, with salaries and bonuses for other areas off significantly in recent years vs. its competitors
cons: Like other Firms on Wall St., there is still  a "partnership model", with a heavy focus on rank (e.g. Managing Directors are most important). Getting promoted can be very political, and involves having good timing and a strong sponsor, and is less about ability.

pros:
Vacation time- 4 weeks total including a mandatory 2 week vacation
Overall company culture is great including the emphasis on volunteer work
Great CEO
cons: It's an absolute shame that employees that help your firm make money is paid severely below market value. In addition, upper management seems to look down upon the Baltimore office ( a very A team/B team mentality at play).  Upper management does not seem to care about employees' career paths- they'll ask you because they're supposed to but mine have never acted upon the things I mentioned in those meetings. If you are interested in coming here- do your best in your given role, learn as much as you can, and leave for another company that will pay you correctly and support you as an employee.

job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The salaries are competitive, facilities are great, benefits are generous. Some of the managers are extremely bright, talented individuals. Everyone is very nice, but that can be similar in other investment banks. The people really make a difference between enjoying your work and hating it. Many of the young people share similar characteristics, so they can be your friends as well as your colleagues. There is room for personal growth, but you must be aggressive. Right out of college, the salary is around 60k for analysts in the operations department, and expect about 10k as a sign on cash bonus.
cons: It seems that senior management may have a hard time listening to ideas. Maybe the compensation may be fuel to overconfidence--egos are nothing short. There are good times and there are bad times for every company, and for each person there is a different story to tell. Most importantly, working with good people is an important factor to individual satisfaction. For the people who simply do their work everyday, it may not be as exciting. I have had trouble communicating ideas to managers--they may ignore good suggestions based on title. Respect and title means a lot in this firm, so do not expect a meritocracy.

pros:
"Big company", everything is done through process. If you've previously worked in a small company you probably experienced chaos, half-done specifications or lack of knowledge about processes. Here everything works like a machine. Definitely a good place to learn how to do processes correctly.

Not very innovative technology wise, but still enough to keep you entertained from time to time. If you consider yourself a "good" programmer and can (for example) write a client-server chat application in assembly, then for you this will be a place to relax and collect money.

Many training programs and employees are encouraged to learn the business side of the project they're working on.

Good salary.
cons:
Very restricted environment, no access to Facebook, GMail, or even Google Translate! Also some tech forums are blocked, and most likely your mother/wife can't send you an email cause her email will get filtered.

Almost every technology or framework is developed in-house. If one day you quit the company, some of your experience won't be of any use to you anymore.

Some people are just a**holes and there's nothing you can do about that since they're on the other side of the world. This becomes a problem if you have to work with them every day. 
Most people are nice, thought.

pros: Gives you the illusion you are a valued employee with countless options to become successful, but....
cons: ....not as exactly as advertised. I was lucky, one of the lucky few that realized that once you have the tools to become a successful Financial Advisor you leave quickly when your guaranteed salary expires, to earn a living wage outside as an independent advisor to get away from the elephant in the room, the grid payout. There are no tools or support (especially support from corporate to market for clients) that will make you successful. If you are a Tier 1, other successful Advisors or groups will try to "team" with you to help you build. Or they are actually doing is try to lock up your AUM if you fail or leave, so other advisors don't get access to your book. You also can become a slave to their practice doing all the menial work keeping you from the prospecting you need to do to survive. Hiring you is just a scam for you to bring another 5-10 million of new assets into Morgan Stanley until you fail.

review_title: Underpaid, no work life balance, no room for growth

Benefits

Nice building amenities- up to date office space, free coffee/tea, new software

Causes issues when trying to improve processes... again all goes back to not getting paid enough for the amount of work expected.

pros: No pros only cons in this company

review_title: Good company but not good Tech company

review_title: Good work/life balance, good treatment of employees
job_title: Vice President, Technology in London, England
pros:
Morgan Stanley in general will treat its employees fairly and well. There are of course obligatory training (compliance, diversity, Know-Your-Customer etc) and there is required approval process for any personal trading, but these both points are regulatory requirements to any front-desk facing job in banking, so cannot hold it against them.

The work environment is relatively relaxed compared to other banks and the managers are rather friendly. When I had trouble with my health (not preventing any work, but making commute rather inconvenient) they allowed work from home for extended time, until I got better. They do not like employees working crazy hours and seem to have checks (or at least, managers' good will) to prevent burn out. Also they have decent candidate selection  (and annual review, later one) process, meaning you are more likely to work with good developers than with poor ones.
cons: If you are a permie software developer, your base salary and bonus will be capped - no matter how good you are. This is common in banking, and one way out of this bracket is move to contracting. You are unlikely to be promoted, unless you have worked at the firm for many years.

review_title: Low pay if you begin as trainee
pros:
1. Brand name is good, and also a powerful bank.
2. Training opportunity in New York, where you can systematically learn a lot of technologies.
3. You have the opportunity to work with smart people and embrace new technologies. 
4. Their IT infrastructure is the best I have seen so far.
cons:
1. Salary of trainees barely aligned with market average.
2. If you unfortunately work in team that sits far far away in the back office (almost no interaction with front desk), and you are more comfortable with coding rather than talking/managing, your annual salary increase and compensation might be small, or barely match inflation rate. One year may be okay. But if you stay there for a few years, you will find yourself significantly underpaid, compared to your peers hired from the market who do the same daily job as yours.
3. Workload and responsibility is too much for the salary they pay.
4. As with all large companies, bureaucracy is everywhere. You have to make your performance visible to MD+ level to get your effort somewhat appreciated.

review_title: If you want to work with really bright people, this is the place
job_title: Technology Associate in New York, NY

In my experience, responsibility assigned has been based on merit, so there's decent recognition of achievements and contributions.
There's also a lot of support for mobility within the organization if one feels they're stagnating or want a steeper learning  curve. The compensation  (up until last year) was a pretty fair mix of individual performance and the larger team and firm achievements.

You get to learn about various technologies and some basics about finance. For new grads, do the training in NYC, come back to Montreal, and find something else.
cons: Once you come back from the TAP to Montreal, the honeymoon phase is over. It's like flipping a coin: you might get in a good coin, or you might get into a bad one. Some of the employees there are dinosaurs that are unwilling and/or incapable of even considering that there is new and better technology out there, and are simply stuck in their old ways. Some other teams are fantastic with very competent people. There seems to be a lot of office politics. Before leaving, I spent nearly 5 months doing very minimal work, waiting for another team to deliver their part of some project, but their funding had been cut.

review_title: Progressively worse over the last 3 years

Even for internal mobility. Therefore people can stuck in the same role for a while.

review_title: Extraordinarily difficult if you're young; best job if you are already really connected
job_title: Financial Advisor Trainee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
They really do invest in your training in the beginning and make sure that you pass all your tests. 
Management is talented, knowledgeable, and willing to share.
Office environment is competitive and open to trying new marketing ideas.
cons:
The quota is extremely high so it really is true that you should try to attempt this if (1) you already know a family member to give you $2M in the beginning to manage to make it through the first year, (2) people trust you in the capacity to give you money to manage.

cons: Well it takes a lot of convincing to bring in new technology as people are skeptical to adapt. Some projects run on really outdated tech stack. review_title: If you want to make money, go into the money business.
job_title: Registered Client Service Associate in Allentown, PA

They like to give advice, which is often more valuable than the cash bonus. LOTS of resources if you want to learn and progress in your career. cons: A bit of a bureaucracy -  It can be awhile for things to actually get changed. Paperwork and service work can get monotonous after awhile, but I don't imagine anyone would want to make a life long career out of it. You become progressively more valuable the longer you stay, since you begin to know the adviser's book of clients inside and out.

review_title: Good for the benefits but far too politic inside
pros: Salaries are pretty much at market, the company also offers some reasonable benefits and the work/life balance is well encouraged. It is indeed possible to take time off (in reasonable amounts!) and to work from home if you really have to. Morgan Stanley is a well-known bank and most of the business is done because of the "Morgan Stanley brand". The company shows a very good face to its clients, hiding how hard it actually is internally to properly manage a portfolio, correctly value it or even manage its risk. The company is surviving because of the name, nothing else.
cons: Morgan Stanley is a company with a few very good people at the very top and the very bottom i.e company management and associate/VP professionals. Between them, you have too many people who are incompetent, spending their day in meeting rooms, playing the politics and getting nothing done. Too many people in this firm are making a full-time job trying to save their own job, finding people to blame for the things they cannot get done. It is not a meritocracy at all, the company survives by its name while, at the same time, it is run on unadequate IT systems, and incompetent managers.

job_title: Senior Registered Associate in New York, NY

But if you keep you head down and work on a good team, you can slip by unnoticed by all the legal and compliance people who monitor EVERYTHING EVERY Employee does everyday, from trades and email to what websites you go on and who you talk to on the phone!

review_title: Competitive compensation, however, culture and atmosphere is current toxic

review_title: Great Company to get licenses; however, cannot trust advisors.
