Nepotism is highly regarded in most offices, and their is "NO" incentive given to your success.  Basically, the senior advisors use you for new revenue , and management encourages this behavior.

pros: Culture of the company is great.  Business users will usually be engaged and constructive.  Lot of opportunities if you're in the right team/location.
cons:
At a very fundamental level conservative technology decisions are made that impact the whole firm.  This is understandable given the highly regulated nature of the company and the large nature of the company.    But it can feel like you're spending a lot of time learning to do things the Morgan way with their very proprietary tech stack.

Also there are the usual problems with technology in the Finance industry generally being treated as lower tier citizen of the firm.

pros: The name, brand, and saying you working at Morgan Stanley make people notice it on the resume.  Other than that there is no advantage as far as pay or career advancement is involved.  Management is involved with a lot of nepotism.
cons: The environment is a sweatshop where you work over 12 hours per day with little to no reward.  You can work on weekends no effect.  There are small groups within MS that are spectacular but, again, you need a connection to get in.  The majority of the firm is run as fiefdoms where there is a lack of foresight to a singular goal.  The bad part is there is a ton of cronyism and nepotism involved where if you don't belong to a certain stereotype that is prevalent in a group, then you don't advance.

review_title: There's a reason people tend to stay...
pros:
Diverse work. If you have the right skills and the right management over you, you can get the space to go out and do some pioneering, to figure out what the firm needs and go deliver it. 
Great quote from former president Bob Scott: If you can't respect your manager, don't stick it out but find yourself a better place to work.
Not everyone is that open and level headed but generally there are quite a few real people in the firm.
cons:
It's less fun if you get stuck with a micro-manager or arrogant know-nothing over you. In TK, work-life balance... with MUFG coming in things are bound to get more stuffy and rigid Japanese style.
Bad quote from former president Zoe Cruz: Really, our business model is much better than a decade ago, because we can lay off most of our risk in the market and so increase leverage and profits (...just a couple of years before the global credit crunch almost killed the over-leveraged firm).

review_title: MSSB should hire just professional hires OR hire people they believe will be good FAs and SUPPORT them.
pros:
Good place to get licenses and industry education
Inside look at how a large wire house works
Good research available
Fairly easy to get hired based on the quality of other FAs I have met
cons:
Poor leadership - managers look out for themselves first!
Poor support of new hires
You pay all own expenses
Understand you are required to generate your first years salary in revenue before making a dime in commission.  You cannot achieve this just by putting clients into managed money programs.  You have to sell high commission products - life insurance and annuities.
Senior brokers prey on new brokers
You can be let go at anytime even if you have money moving in that will make your numbers
No admin support for new FAs
Message is you are expendable!!!
Expectation is you will have no life for 3 years to build your book
Poor internal systems
Not a teamwork based environment
Unless you are being hired into a team and guaranteed thresholds to meet numbers, I would not recommend joining this company
Still very much a 'good old boy' company; not female friendly

review_title: Good company to learn, needs to update
pros:
-Great Training Programs
-Lots of opportunities to get involved in committees, build a network, etc. 
-Very smart, ambitious people
- Great firm reputation
-If you need help, someone is always will to help, even if you have to escalate something high in the organization. 
-Learn about how a big company work effectively through great process, controls, approvals, etc.
cons:
-A lot of your experience will change based on what team you're placed in. It's not very consistent, some people have great managers and reasonable hours, others do not. 
-Be prepared for long hours.
-There is no performance reward at the analyst level. You will get paid and promoted based on primarily time and how your business unit is doing (which you can only minimally effect at that point)
-Change can be slow moving
-The 'Cover your own a**" and fear of mistakes culture isn't a healthy working environment.
-Diversity is not addressed as thoughtfully as it could be.

pros: The work here is very competitive and exciting.  The size of the deals that you do here are huge compared to working at a smaller firm.  There is opportunity for career advancement if you show initiative but if you seem complacent your work will become stale.
cons:
After about a six month learning curve work may seem redundant.  You do have a certain level of autonomy at your function but it might feel like you are living the same day over and over again.
Work can be exciting but stressful.  You might be overseeing millions of dollars in transactions every hour and you could lose alot of money by pushing a wrong button or being a few seconds late pushing that button.  If you are in a cost unit instead of a business unit your work could become obsolete fairly soon.

review_title: Avoid if you want a Work Life Balance
pros: some good people to work with and learn
cons:
Worked at MS for more than 6 years in various different teams. It’s a very toxic atmosphere in most departments, staff turnover is high and morale is low. Managers are promoted who don’t have the necessary people skills to manage people. 
There is a reason the firm is always looking for people, they can never retain their staff. Went from being the newest member of a team of 10 to the most experienced in the space of a year when everyone left.
Expect to do long hours (10 hours a day minimum) and get minimal pay for this. The annual bonus/pay increase is terrible. They do not pay for being loyal, if you want more money, leave and then come back where they will be compelled to offer you the market value
The Firm has a horrible mindset of when an employee leaves make the team carry the weight of the work while a request is made for approving of  a head which can mean months before you have replacement - but that just saves them $$$
I wish i had left sooner, don’t make the same mistake if you want a work, life balance

review_title: Leaving as soon as I can!! That's my title
pros: The best thing about working at Morgan Stanley's you'll be able to resign and get away from those (I had to clean up my language) this is the first class publication I can't complain! That was the only pro I could think of
cons: I am writing a book  Morgan Stanley hands-down the meanest the most of professional worst place to work in the investment business

review_title: Private Wealth Management Client Service Associate
job_title: Client Service Associate in New York, NY
pros: A really incredible company to work for. They really want to make sure employees are taken care of in every aspect. The environment is so welcoming and there is so much to learn. As a CSA in your first 2 years you make a base salary of $55,000 in my case. I am also eligible for over time as well which is a great plus! Great job right out of college and great way to get into a top bank.
cons: Have not received a bonus this year which is surprising. The only thing I have received is $500 added onto one of my paychecks. This can be a tough job to grow in as most of these teams have people running them who have been around the firm for a long time. When they retire they typically hand their books over to the next oldest advisor on the team that isn't retiring.

review_title: Great culture, great co-workers, lots of learning opportuniites.
pros:
* This company lives by the it's posted values.  I love that we have a month of volunteering, adopt a family at Christmas, blood drives, food drives.... etc
* Flexible hours and the ability to work from home when needed.  
* Great co-workers who are willing to share their knowledge about everything and anything.
* Great culture - our social committee does a great job of planning social events, and we have a social hour every Friday.  We also have regular hackathons where we get to expand out of the day-to-day duties and learn something new.
cons: We aren't immune to the problems of any large company.  Growing at the pace we are, and being in the middle of an acquisition adds some growing pains while things get sorted out.  As long as you are willing to have open communication with your managers, and approach with a team mentality you will be able to ride out these bumps with minimal bruising.

review_title: Horrible place to work, unless you like ripping off your clients.
job_title: Registered Client Service Associate in Tampa, FL
pros: The pay was good, office hours were good and the management was nice to work for.
cons: I worked at their Client Advisory Center which was a big title for a call center.  Morgan Stanley is a horrible company to their smaller net worth clients.  If you had less than $100,000 invested with them, their local financial advisors no longer got paid anything for them so they were encouraged to send them to the call center.  The smaller customers get ripped off completely with very high low balance fees and terrible customer service.  The training was horrible, and the ethics of Morgan Stanley are non-existent.   Many of the smaller net worth clients were not very financially educated and Morgan Stanley took advantage of this.  We were not allowed to tell them about the fees they were getting charged, only  if they happened to look at their statement and notice the rip off. If we brought the fee structure up to the customer we could get fired.  They charged these outrageous fees and hoped the customers would ignore their statements or just not savvy enough to figure it out. Horrible horrible company to work for and worse for their unwitting clients.

review_title: Nice place to work, good technology culture!
pros:
- great technology infrastructure (definitely missed it after leaving for a smaller company)
- many people with lots of technical experience that are more than willing to answer questions and help out!
- excellent training program for new grads (this is really a great experience and you get to meet and work with people from around the world)
- related to previous point: the company is massive and it's exciting working with people from around the world
cons:
- lower pay than other companies and rarely willing to negotiate salary for younger employees
- doesn't do enough to keep young people staying there (should be willing to pay higher salaries and try harder to put new grads in more exciting positions)
- business dress code is enforced even in offices such as Montreal where it is almost entirely filled with Software Developers

review_title: What goes on at ms is what makes people hate corporate America
job_title: Senior Registered Sales Assistant in New York, NY
pros: There are two good things about working her, It looks good on a resume and the the day you leave.
cons: Terrible compensation packages, the way the firm treats employees is what makes people hate corporate America. The CEO James Gorman gives himself raises and bonus' numerous times a year, millions upon millions of dollars, but they lay off tons of people making low salaries and expect people to do the job of two people. They rob from the advisors putting a portion of their revenue in a differed comp plan. They use that money to buy Morgan Stanley stock moving up the price of the stock which makes Gorman stock options more valuable. They treat support staff like the own them, no bonus, years go by without raises, then when they give you one it's less than 1 percent of your salary. I repeatedly got high ratings on my performance reviews and the big raise would be less than one percent, some people got nothing. This is the worst firm on Wall Street. The culture is negative and counter productive. They couldn't give a hoot about their employees.

pros:
Well paid, very good insurance, retirement plan contributions.
Felt welcomed from day 1, people are very friendly and nice to hang out with after work when there is an event.
The culture and politics (like diversity, workplace harassment, equality) was very well defined and I felt like it was actually enforced.
Offices in Montreal have standing desks.
cons:
Terrible banking style, lots of management, doesn't move fast, tedious unnecessary meetings, hard to focus because people are always talking or there are constant interruption.
Some things were good technology wise, but most of it was very old and update meant copy pasting code.
The work was just not fun, spending a lot of time in 15+ years old systems. Saw some truly horrendous code. Wouldn't recommend for people out of school because you will not learn anything valuable. Your skills will degenerate quickly as you will not really "code" per say because most of the tasks are artificial.

I would say the job is closer to a business analyst than a technologist.

review_title: A bit of a hit and miss unfortunately...
pros:
1. There are the very few genuinely good staff who are technically good and can collaborate
2. Seating away from trading floor so less interuptions, depending on teams of course
3. The occasional flexible working from home (although this is quite common amongst larger banks)
cons:
1. Disconnected and bureaucratic management chain
2. Undervalue high performing staff until they resign after which they become "critical"
3. Focusing on the wrong strategy and expecting "someone else" to pick it up
4. Benefits below par on what other banks offer and there's an upper cap on standard offerings
5. Don't expect a fast career progression track (granted this experience is just one of the many teams) do your research on teams

pros: If you only have your FINRA 7 and 66 you can get your series 9 and 10. Mostly good coworkers. Good entry level principal work, mainly mindless work. Flexibility, not micro managed as far as breaks. Immediate managers care, even if other managers don’t.
cons: Recruiters will lie to you about work from home. There is no work from home. Dishonest policies. Sweat shop mentality, understaffed so you will do the work of two people. Training non existent, policies change without communication. Opinions not valued, even though inexperienced leadership doesn’t understand the work. Monotonous work that rarely utilizes your licenses. Pay raises not fair, bad employees and top performers treated the same. At best this role is a place to get your licenses and move on as there is very little career advancement.

job_title: Wealth Advisory Associate in Boston, MA
pros: Newer position that allows you to run financial plans for senior financial advisers. You are able to develop nonthreatening relationships with advisers with the goal of potential teaming or joint partnership opportunities. A very good way to learn the wealth management business for a year plus without having the pressure of bringing in business
cons: Tracking system for financial plans is not perfect.  It really depends on your office as to whether advisers believe in the financial planning process.  Some offices might make it tough to reach any type of bonus.  Transition to a Financial Adviser Associate happens quickly.  Make sure you are prepared from the start. Your FAA month 0 is your last month of WAA.

review_title: Great working culture but compensation gap means they're losing good people
pros:
Operations in Morgan Stanley is a great place to work which operates well for a large firm. The culture is results driven and there is a constant drive for improvement. 

Internal mobility is encouraged on the face of things but it requires support from your management team for anything to happen. 

Technology is way ahead of the vast majority of the street and a large budget is reserved for development. 

Internal training materials are great and employees are encouraged to develop themselves whilst working at MS
cons:
Compensation is far behind the other IBs for operations, which means that lots of people start to look elsewhere when bonuses and salary increases are not in line with expectations. This means that they lose a lot of talented grads 2-3 years in.

Management in certain areas can be too focused on their own career without caring for the careers of those under them.

Whilst work life balance is far from terrible some areas can expect an amount of face time, even when work has been done for the day

review_title: The Critical Issue is the Absence of Leaders
pros: Compensation, benefits, vacation days, unlimited sick, museum passes
cons: There is ZERO leadership training. Upper management is filled with unqualified "managers" who should not be in leaderships roles just because they are more experienced. "Managers" have an absence of any sort of innate leadership qualities. Just because you can play the game, does NOT mean you should be a coach.   They act like you do not understand, belittle your opinions, don't acknowledge your ideas, use your past to avoid their present wrongdoings and inject fear in you to conform to them . Teams consistently suffer from burnout, no one provides direction , people are constantly complaining about how unhappy they are everyday.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Some friendly, social people. Opportunity to follow some interesting financial investments.
cons: The clients are all angry, retired pensioners with nothing better to do than call you up 20 times a day asking about their missing $0.50 div check or blame you for the market taking a nose dive. You are GLUED to your office land line because the phones are the primary means of communication in that business so you are not allowed to leave your desk if no one is available to cover your line. Not for lunch, the bathroom, anything. Some coworkers are douchey, money hungry "Wolf of Wall St" types who think they'll all be millionaires in a few weeks time, only to find how easy it is to wash out of that business without a stable book of clients behind them. I've seen so many people quit or get fired in my time there because the pressure to land clients got to them. Bottom line - It's a high pressure sales job, at the end of the day.

pros:
1) MSSB paid for Series 7 and Series 66
2) Experience life in Corporate Shark Tank
3) Access to MSSB analysis
4) Powerful Name
5) Good benefits
cons:
1) Cut Throat and Back Stabbing Culture
2) Lack of transparency regarding time table; MGMT reneged on time table
3) You are on your own.  Can not trust MGMT or Senior FAs.  Everyman for himself mentality. MGMT says has amnesia about past conversations. Can not trust MGMT
4) Only way to succeed at the FAA role is having having family money or have extensive list of close friends who are millionaires 
5) Business model is to bring in new FAA, use FAA's contacts to close business, give FAA a small % of commission on his leads, then kick FAA out the door when all contacts on his list have been worked
6) MSSB provides no leads or old clients to manage
7) Senior FAs are very predatory and promise the world but will not sign partnering contract before closing FAA's prospects

job_title: Financial Advisor Trainee in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The firm obviously is one of the few to survive to major market crash and carries a solid reputation.  They have their own research division which pumps out some top notch market research and provides actionable opportunities for their brokers.  The office was well appointed and the computer tools were very nice.
cons: The trainee program was well intended but poorly executed.  The mentorship program was a total joke, and it's a real shame because a good mentor can make a world of difference.  Obviously, this is a sales oriented type position where you are selling yourself, but inter-office competition is very high so brokers were not likely to help each other too much.  The sales manager at the time sorely lacked management capability, though I believe he has since left the company.  Too focused on cold calling and not enough on finding better ways (existing connections) to attract clients.

pros: Morgan Stanley is the biggest investment firm.  They have a very wide variety of products and experts that are available and responsive. They do provide a good amount of time to study for the 7 and 66 exams.
cons:
You will get zero support as a new advisor.  You will complete all new client forms yourself and receive zero leads.  People do not call Morgan Stanley looking for an advisor.  As a new advisor you will be given a cube and phone and basicly wished "good luck" Because you know people does not mean they will change from their current advisor.  The days of making multiple phone calls hoping to find a new client are basicly over with blocks call etc.

It can be done, but the odds are very high against making a go of it with this firm.  Ask what percentage of new advisors stay with the firm.

pros: It is a good looking experience in your CV, you might work with some of the greatest minds in your area. The compensation is above average.
cons: You have a good chance of being employed by a third-party employer which will lend your work to Morgan Stanley. This causes some very unfortunate discrepancies in entitlements, you will not get a yearly bonus or pay rise even until you are "converted" full-time employee, which I find ridiculous because you go through the same selection process you do the same work, so it is strictly budgeting decision.  The career path is very not clear, the superiors are not supportive. In the 1 year, I spent here I did not get a single performance review.  I think the company is overstaffed due to the high level of fluctuation, I could do my job in 25% of the time. I think this was a good experience for me to not be looking to work in a similar place again.

job_title: Vice President Operations in Purchase, NY
pros: Premier investment company. You will get some good experience although the approach is much more segmented. This allows management to plug and play people instead of developing a more broad knowledged individual. This is also why people leave the firm- lack of training and a dead end job.
cons: The company has changed alot over the years- you feel like a number. They don't value effort any more- it's about dollars and sense even if that means putting people in seats that don't know what they are doing to save 20k a head. Sad but that is what the firm has come to. Poor leadership from the top- manage by fear not by what you can accomplish.

job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in Portland, OR
pros: Good pay and fun relationships with coworkers.
cons:
This place is the ultimate meritocracy, and you are going to learn quite a bit about the engine of capitalism.  

If you are new to the business, they will partner you with a senior advisor who has one goal in working with you:  have you help him raise as many assets as possible for him.  These people will sink their teeth into your most personal relationships that  your job is to tee them up with.  Additionally, you will be cold calling all day for years.  This firm provides zero resources in terms of giving you an existing book of assets to manage, or any real leads to call.  Do not expose your relationships to Senior FAs, as these people are polished and master manipulators ... will spin you around and spit you out.  Some of the things you'll see in this environment will be very strange and leave you scratching your head.  

Good place to start your career but ultimately not a good place to build a career.  Might be a good place to end a career.  One year of training with a salary would be perfect for a new advisor.  After that, find a smaller firm.

review_title: Great at providing challenges, will look to underpay wherever they can get away with it
pros:
Challenging 
Encourages growth (personal and professional)
cons: Operations consistently look to under pay as part of their business model, particularly if talent has been grown from within. Including willingness to go below their own pay brackets at all levels, if the person has risen through the ranks.

pros: The ability to work in multiple branches gives you exposure to many different teams. The employees in the branches were very kind and very transparent. You are allowed to take as many license exams as you wish and it is encouraged.
cons: The program is unorganized and lacks direction. The communication between the program heads and the branches where the analyst work is very poor. If you aren't proactive you can end up getting lost in the shuffle and not having a role. If you are proactive it may be seen as dissatisfaction. If you have prior finance experience or hands on internships this job is a step back.

review_title: Solid opportunities for the right individuals.
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Morgan Stanley has still maintained a solid reputation amidst the current market situation. There are opportunities for growth if you seek it. You will be pushed to excel unless you resist. Professionally there are people that you will find here that are invaluable to your career. Many people have worked for MS for a very long time. Even if they do a stint at another firm, they eventually return. Therefore, the level of home-grown institutional knowledge at the middle to upper management level is what makes MS stand out. Additionally, on a social level there are many chances to continue to grow your network outside of the office at the local pubs. Above all else the people here are what make it great coming to work everyday.
cons:
Lack of technology resources for the support units. Manual processes inhibit the firm from getting to the next level it needs to reach on the street. 

"Face time."

review_title: Bad Experience because of team I was in.
pros:
1:Company is very good
2:Work from home.
3:Unlimited sick leaves.
4:Free Cabs.
5:Overall very good investment bank.
6:15  holidays.
cons:
1:Company takes advantage of people and give them contractual offers after clearing 5-6 rounds of interview and tell them to join from Pride and optimum search or some other unknown consultancies with very high salary (Never accept contractual position don't get trapped )

2:They take interview like they will make rockets from you but once you are in  you have do support and clear dirt everday.

3:My team was very bad no support from team members are like wolfs never supports you.
4:No KT for new members you have to understand application by debugging.
5:Old team members are spoiling environment.

review_title: The Good, the Bad, the Ugly
pros: More the most part everyone is really nice, and everyone gets along.  The office building is nice, and there is a gym available for those that want to use it.
cons: Getting supplies is very hard, people have to hide Letterhead and when you do ask for it you only get a few sheets at a time.  They only get basic supplies and if you need or want something particular you have to pay out of pocket.  They don't pay for parking, which is over $200 a month no matter where you park.

review_title: Local Management Undercut by Regional Management
job_title: Client Service Associate in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I had one of the best managers of my working career. She was kind, compassionate, and encouraged personal growth.  Co-workers were eager to help and essential to the learning process.  Work could be very interesting and challenging.
cons: Excellent manager mentioned above was overworked, driven to tears, and quit, during  a transitional period.  Regional management was incredibly poor after transition, disillusioning local workers.  Worked closely with Financial Advisors, some of whom would barely work (2-4 hours a day), had little understanding of my job, despite being hyper critical and having unreasonable expectations.    Some of them had business practices that made me question their ethics as well.  That being said some of my FAs were kind, understanding, hardworkers, who had  ethical business practices.  Some managers were also in producing positions, which created clear and obvious conflicts of interest.

review_title: MS is a place for bright people that want to work in a collaborative environment offering excellent career development.
job_title: Investment Banking Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: At Morgan Stanley, I am surrounded by the brightest minds in the banking industry. There is a tremendous culture focused on first-rate client service, which is achieved by hiring and developing talented people that share an enthusiastic and collaborative vision and drive. Compensation is linked to personal, group, and firm performance, which encourages each person to perform at his or her highest potential. Feedback from colleagues is thoughtful, and often informal. Senior management does a great job of training junior people in the business of investment banking and of sharing strategic information about the issues and opportunities facing the group and bank.
cons: The largest downside of working at any investment bank is the riskiness associated with employment on Wall Street. Like all investment banks, Morgan Stanley has had to lay off some of its bankers to keep costs reasonable in the face of an economic downturn.

review_title: Good place to obtain securities licenses
job_title: Financial Advisor Trainee in Chicago, IL
pros: If you can get your foot in the door and can live on a very modest salary for a year, you'll have benefits and a chance to study and take your securities and insurance license exams.
cons: If you don't pass your series 6 and 7 the first time you are immediately terminated.  Commissions and trails on mutual fund sales are only around 1%.  Morgan Stanley gives you about 30% of that 1%.  So if you have a million dollars in assets under management you'll earn $3,000. Pretty tough.  Life insurance sales are around 4%.  This information is from 2008, so compensation might a bit different

review_title: Good Place to start your career
pros:
People- I truly like 99% of the people that I work with, yes there are some unkind people but they are few and far between
Benefits- 4% 401k match with vesting after 3 years,  16 weeks maternity leave, 4 weeks vacation when first starting, Cell phone discount, etc.
Work Opportunities- given lots of opportunities to learn and grow
cons:
Work/Life Balance- be prepared to work more than 8 hours a day while not getting overtime, also if you are a good worker be prepared to get more responsibilities
Compensation- after promotion to Associate from Analyst, I make less money
 then before due to overtime eligibility for Analyst only but do more work
Career Direction- no clear path to getting promoted and no mentor-ship program
Parking- not subsidized by the company, so you will be paying easily over $100 a month
No Formal Training-came straight from college and was throw into work straight away

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Location.  Worked in other companies their systems of accessing docs and opening new accounts requiring approval of various departments are one of the best.
cons: Depends what group or area is worked for.  I understand other groups where as widely publicized that you can work from home and be able to raise a family my area was all about show, everyone stayed as late as the boss and when the boss was away of business trip they left at decent hours.  I was sick one day and was still asked to come in even though I had worked from home all night and was still able to be logged in.  Their computerized systems shows when your computer goes to sleep to whomever has you listed in the internal IM system, so they know that you are logged in working even from home, but that was not enough.

review_title: How to waste two years of your life
pros: The graduate training scheme is unparalleled, a wonderful learning experience. For the first fifteen weeks of your career, you will feel like you made the right decision.
cons: A corporate policy of Morgan Stanley is that there can be no promotion until you have served a total of nine years in higher education and the financial industry. If you have a bachelors degree, you will spend six years without any appreciable increase in salary or rank. The average bonus for new hires now is below three thousand, and the average raise is close to zero. There is a split culture; those who arrived before the crisis, in the "good times", still brag about wealth and insist on the best Champagne. For new hires, however, that could not be further from the truth. It is a long standing open secret that Morgan Stanley has the worst graduate salary of any large investment bank; the expectation being with advancement comes significant monetary improvements. What is likely to take you by surprise is that until the first promotion (6 years), the expected raise is zero.

review_title: Mixed bag working for IT at MS
job_title: IT Associate in New York, NY
pros: There are some very talented and brilliant people at Morgan Stanley...  it is a great place to learn and grow.  Like any large corporation, it can be a great place to work, if you work for/with great people.  They do foster an environment where mobility is encouraged; I know of several people who have been there for 15+ years in various roles over time.
cons: Their HR pamphlet speaks of a "work/life balance" that the company supposedly promotes.  In reality, in IT I have not seen that balance, particularly among infrastructure teams.  I have seen people work 20+ hour weekend shifts with no sleep breaks.  Also, it is very common in IT (more often than not) that people get promoted but do not get the salary bump to match it.   Also, year-end bonuses in IT have been few and far between, and not very generous.  I have seen many talented people leave for greener pastures at other companies.

review_title: A good mix of new and old technology while learning the financial business
pros:
-Work life balance is great, I can work from home as much as I want and the schedule is super flexible. I worked from across the country for multi-week and will work from abroad for a month soon.
-My immediate manager are great and always fighting for their colleague
-Good perks (RRSP matching, gym membership, etc...)
-Excellent graduate program where you spend 4 months in NYC to learn more about technology with pretty much all-expense paid
cons:
-Even though my team use recent technology and that my direct managers are really great technologist, it is obvious that most other team spend most of their time supporting old software on old stack.
-Difficult to get a raise since 2008 even though the company make more and more money
-

job_title: Client Service Associate in Boston, MA
pros: You'll work with some extremely intelligent and successful people. The company had a great name and is a wonderful launch point for a career in wealth management and financial advising. They also sponsor you for your Series exams and you have many opportunities for incentive/bonus pay. Overall, people are generally friendly and willing to help you with your work.
cons: Unfortunately, I must say that a lot of politics and favoritism is involved in advancement and preferential treatment. Unless your in a group of favorites, you can get absolutely screwed. During my time here, I have seen my manager, who was extremely competent and had my deep respect leave due to the culture. The workload can sometimes be high pressure, depending on the advisors you work with. There are a lot of big egos. One further warning, steer clear of office gossip.

review_title: Dream company for the right motivated individual
job_title: Financial Representative Trainee in Binghamton, NY
pros: If you are good at your job you will move up in the company and enjoy many perks.  It is all about how many clients you can bring in and the quality of clients (i.e. amount of money they bring with them).  You build up your own client list
cons: It's not for everyone.  You have to be a go-getting type of person with an entrepreneurial spirit who doesn't mind cold calling to acquire clients and build a book.  How well you do here literally depends upon you.  The salary is nice but most of your pay will come at the end of the year in the form of a lump sum bonus.  If you don't get a bonus, well then, don't expect to be with the company much longer unless you make some serious changes for the better.

review_title: Excellent company; success really is up to you
job_title: Associate Wealth Management Advisor in Fresno, CA
pros: I can only speak for the Fresno office, as I can almost certainly say that each individual office in varying cities will have different "vibes". Absolutely top-notch trading platforms and industry-leading portfolio options. Management was hands-off and allowed me to do my job the way I was most comfortable. Kind, healthy work environment- a very positive, balanced culture, as well. Senior brokers were willing and eager to help when questions arose.
cons: You must pass your Series 7 on the first attempt. I did. You must pass your Series 66 by second attempt. This is where i failed. I can't blame anyone but myself. I will say this: The STC training software that prepares you for the exam is markedly different in terms of quality when comparing the Series 7 and 66 study materials. I wish there were more "on-demand" or live classes to keep me engaged. Once you pass the "7", your brain is fried... but you still have more to do!

pros: You can build a huge network. Practice English. Get to know  company philosophy and financial markets. Free lunches at expensive restaurants. Stable workplace. Salary paid before the end of month. Water fountains. Ice cream vending machines. A lot of smart people. Relatively good salary. Lectures organised time by time. Massage was possible at workplace. Sometimes friendly people. Free bank account at Citibank.
cons: Bosses have full control.  They may pretend to be friendly. You may judged superficially. Pseudo- democracy. Survival of fittest. Poor quality sausages. Long working hours. Low integrity (supposed to be a value in the company). Some people are afraid, distrust. Many people are smart but can have low morality and low empathy. Not always reasonable.  Unreasonable demands.  Not enough testing environment.  Could not work because of that .Some people can get offended too easily.  The boss threatened/bullied/ false accusations. (Not all bosses did that) Broken words, disinformation? (Not all bosses did that)  Office was too hot in summer. (That is not a general problem). Boss with extreme temper.

pros:
CEO is visionary.
Business is well connected with Policy makers so can survive any recession.
Business can pretty much manage without IT. 
Very good in managing PR and branding.
Excellent place to learn corporate politics.
cons: There are 2 organization inside Morgan & Stanley both terrible however one is worse than other. Your experience depends on which part you belong. IT is more like a toilet in a mansion. There is profiling everywhere & no place to dissent.  Management culture like my way or highway no discussion on critical issues. High velocity ZERO displacement workplace. Open culture is hollow & only exists on paper. Titles are just eyewash don't count on it it means NOTHING of course it comes for free from management point of view. Thousands and thousands of Executive/Managing Directors are there to just say YES BOSS with no voice of their own. Internal culture is SICK. Your have been warned join at your own risk.

pros: Slightly higher than average annual fixed salary, and good health insurance benefit
cons: Stingy and abusive demanding managers,  frequent inter-team conflicts. long working hours with unpaid overtime and unpaid weekend hours,  cut in yearly bonuses,  stagnant salaries,  lack of clear company directions, outdated technology,  majority cheap offshoring &  AI replacement worker abuses.

job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
- Good Training Programs
- Flexible work schedule
- Ability to work from home
- Good Pay
cons:
"You will loose your skills, dignity and job over a period of time"

Career prospects in IT are bad. Morgan Stanley is an outsourcing factory. They hire people in India, transfer knowledge to them then lay you off. Most people in IT feel they are the next lamb of slaughter. This is how it works. They will introduce you to a few consultants, then they will ask questions about application and you will help them set up.. They will then be assigned new tasks and you will help them cross train. Slowly they will do the work and you will be on sidelined. After 6-12 months when management feels consultants know most of the application, you will be marked for layoff. Consultants then will be hired as full time employees at Morgan Stanley in India. My colleagues who have been with firm for 15-20 years are now training their replacements.

It is a terrifying situation for technology professionals. 

If you are an IT professional, go somewhere else.

pros: Some smart people there, especially within their field
cons:
WARNING TO WOMEN: I had a boss that harassed me on a daily occurrence for over 4 months, the details of which are definitely 'crossing the line'. I refused to do something that was against the code of conduct and borderline illegal and that was the repercussion.
I went through the appropriate channels, HR, asking to be directed to someone else in the Firm, etc. He wanted me under his control, and fought me and another Director when I asked to be transferred to another Director within my small 10 person team. He would often threaten that "he knew how to manipulate senior management".
4 months later I was laid off, and during the separation talk the MD on the team didn't understand why I was being laid off but signed off on it since my former boss suggest my name (if you didn't know that's how the lay offs work at Morgan, now you do...someone suggests your name).

pros: Morgan Stanley is a strong and good company.  Opportunities are there, but because it is so large it is difficult to be small starting out, and you are often lost in the mix.  Be very concerned with your branch and its management, because it has a huge impact on whether you will get the resources you need to succeed or not.
cons: You really need mentorship early on, and if you are not in a well organized branch, or if you are in a branch where the branch manager is also in production (i.e., worried about his/her own book of business) you will not get much coaching or supervision.

review_title: Industry Powerhouse who lacks negative publicity
job_title: Client Service Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: MS offers it all, a full immersion into the world of finance and all the great things to offer. I find my colleagues to be like minded, dedicated, and honest. I do not feel that anyone is trying to outdo anyone else and that there is more of a team environment then I would have ever expected. I highly recommend MS to anyone interested in great career growth and empowerment. A lot can be achieved with such a great experience.
cons: There is quite a bit of disparity in age. Having this can make it often times difficult to be on the same page with seniors who are unaware of changing environments and matters faced by the younger generations. You can find that unless you really push, you are often pigeon holed in your current role making it difficult to rise up.

review_title: It's still the dog-eat dog, client-last, boiler room culture of the 1980s
job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in Harrisburg, PA
pros: If you are the family member of a senior employee, you will be set for life,  Compensation structure, even after the restructuring for FA comp, is still very generous
cons:
To succeed, at least at first, you need to put your own ethics on the back burner and be comfortable with hurting your clients.  That is, if you don't, you won't make enough revenue to keep your job.  

Now if you are inheriting someone's book of business or joining a team, it's a much different story.

Old style marketing expectations.  Dialing through the telephone book in the days of "Do Not Call Lists" does not work.

Other advisors, at least in my office, will stab you in the back if it means stealing an account from you.  Unfortunately, there is nothing you can do about it since they are senior and have certain privileges.

review_title: For a huge company, Morgan Stanley is pretty good
pros: Environment is encouraging and open, management is easy to access/talk to. Easy to foster relationships in various back-office specialties, even across the country, which makes solving problems and getting questions answered more efficient. Benefits are excellent.
cons: It is almost impossible to get a meaningful raise here if you are support staff. They will promise you one, then end up freezing payroll, then give you a couple thousand bucks the next year. Not a ton of opportunities to move up to other positions. They seem to transfer in Morgan Stanley people in the same position from other offices when something opens, and employees don't find out that the position was open in the first place until it is filled. Management often does not seem to have the power to fix things or get something done.

job_title: Registered Client Service Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: Decent benefits - 401k match (4%), medical/dental, great vision plan, 9 sick days, 3 weeks vacation after 3 years, 16 weeks maternity leave, supportive of working mothers (at least in my branch), backup daycare for working parents (I love this benefit!). The wealth management side of the business is in a much better place now than than it was 10 years ago.  Technology is always improving (mobile app, docuSign for new account/money movement forms, eAuthorization for wire transfers , etc.) and the firm has the resources to develop more efficient processes.  I’m very proud to work here and have no desire to work at another financial services firm.
cons:
-Can feel very bureaucratic due to the size of the firm and sometimes you feel like there are so many obstacles in the way of achieving your goal.  
-CSA comp depends on the generosity of your FA/team.  Some make base salary and others make well over 6 figures.

review_title: Luck will shape your experience here
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
If you happen to pick the right group to join, then your experience can be awesome...at a discounted salary compared to other banks.

There are a lot of fun projects to migrate archaic platforms to a new technology stack.

If you're interested in learning something new or stretching your knowledge, make sure to pick the right group and right boss. You'll know it's the right group when people in that group are smiling and happy even when they are crazy busy.
cons:
Salary is relatively low compared to other banks. However, if you're in the right group, you have the flexibility to learn and do new things that you wouldn't be able to do in other banks.

There's a big chasm between employees who are working on legacy applications versus the employees building the new applications. It's sad because I like the people here.

pros: You do get to experience & learn your role thoroughly. Great systems & processes.
cons: Full of office politics where also once you're in Operations the feel is they don't want you to move elsewhere but Operations. Same Learning Development program running over & over again with no encouragement from management to take on any other course BUT operations related. All and everything seems to be about budgets this & budget that. Seems like the only people left over are the one that does not mind being a Robot or need job security to get ready to start family. Plus we're located in the middle of nowhere! Outside the financial HUB where back-office belongs... No chance to inter-mingle with other banks. Very anti-Social this location is. I believe other location is better than Shanghai/ China.

review_title: It was fine - good place to start
job_title: Registered Sales Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: You see exactly what the brokerage business is all about and if you want to do it you know what you are getting into.  You can learn a lot based on who you work for.
cons: Advancement is tough when you start on the low end of the ladder. Hard to make it to another level unless a broker likes you. Even then still tough. Also if there is ever a problem and depending on who you work for I have seen SA be blamed for things they had no hand in. Easier for the low moral broker to blame someone else than eat their mistake. If something looks bad take notes and protect yourself - just in case you get pushed under the bus.

job_title: Financial Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: I truly believe this to be one of the great firms on the Street.  In my opinion the I Bank, M&A, research, and Capital Markets operations are second to none.
cons: Financial Advisors are lately talking to their clients about the fact that the market as a whole has been focused on the macro issues and largely ignoring fundamentals, thus missing huge opportunities. MSSB is having the same problems.  The senior leadership at the firm is quite frankly outstanding, however, they have not addressed the disparity between the MS and SB offices whatsoever.  While spending their time worrying about the "big issues" branch support has fallen drastically, the average age of advisors continues to climb and their training program remains a largely ineffectual avenue for promoting "organic growth" .

review_title: Great experience, lifetime colleagues, excellent brand recognition
pros: Excellent brand recognition, great way to start a career or move a career forward.  There are a lot of very smart people in the organization to learn from.  Good compensation package, benefits, vacation days.
cons: Morgan Stanley like any investment bank is not for someone looking for a 9-5 job.  You need to be able to dedicate substantial hours to company, but possibly somewhat fewer hours than Goldman Sachs or Citigroup.  The company size may be a negative for some people, because like other large companies Morgan Stanley has a "meeting culture" - there are a lot of meetings and it takes a while to get anything executed.  Getting promoted to higher levels is a bit political and requires you to have a strong network and strong champions/references.

review_title: Misadventures in the land of morgan
pros: Morgan was competitive at first. offering stellar benefits, generous time off, including the ability to work from home. promises of a career first track and the ability to be premoted and earn more.
cons: Morgan's culture can only be described as the gladiators arena, where you are expected to justify your existence constantly to ancillary managers and vps who have no clue about how a team functions or what is required of the job. technology is poor. don't even bother discussing your career track. there is no loyalty to managers or staff by higher ups. Majority of NE staff have been downsized and replaced by consultants from India or off shored in some other way. no bonuses, paper tiles and promotion. pay became very non competitive while you were always expected to twice as much with half the resources.

job_title: Operational Risk Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Competitive pay and benefits with peer institutions
Extremely intelligent and skilled co-workers
Management makes a real effort to support work-life balance
I can't speak for other managers/teams, but I love the MD that I'm reporting to and the team that I'm on
Strong industry name recognition
cons:
Confusing RIF decisions given the firm's performance, and poor internal communication about rationales
While benefits such as healthcare are industry competitive, the costs are still very high for what you get
Weak 401k investment selection (broad range of funds, but all with ridiculously high expense ratios even on the index funds)
No consideration that most employees are not the typical MS client (no breaks on the absurdly high $10.95 online commissions, very little access to no load funds with respectable expense ratios, no discounts on advisory fees)

pros:
Even though the firm is based in New York, we do really important and visible work in the Shanghai office. It's great to know that what we do actually matters.
The firm culture is great, working hours are long but flexible.
I'm very happy with my management line, I got strong support from them and good feedback regarding my work. My colleagues are smart, and the firm organizes special events reasonable frequently.
cons:
Being so far away from the headquarters is not easy, we have to focus a lot on visibility, to get the same recognition.
Salaries after a first few years are not so great, and even though firm management is aware of this, they don't seem to take actions to fix this.
Hours can be long, especially if you have to work with New York or Montreal.

pros: Great exposure to the work environment of a large office. Great learning experience. Really helped me get a better idea of the role of a financial advisor.
cons: Had a lot of excess capacity that my supervisor filled with busy work... Nothing against busy work--I completely understand that part of being an intern is paying your dues and doing the tedious work that others don't want to do--but it felt like this particular busy work wasn't even work that needed to be done. i.e. my supervisor asked me to spend a day reorganizing our client management system despite the fact that they were planning on changing over to a completely new enterprise software system later that month.

pros: More highly technical colleagues than in the other 5 large IBs I have worked over. Turn over among mid level and senior manager is at a healthy enough level to maintain the culture the bank values so much: "doing the right thing". Heavy investment on technology at all levels: hardware, software and people. Critical to join a group where you get to prove yourself woking for a fair and technical manager that has a solid relationship with the business; it is the best way to achieve a sense of stability and fulfillment, and every extra mile you give will get recognized and valued.
cons:
Firm and organization wise, none. It really boils down to granularity, i.e. to the group you get to be part of and your direct manager(s). In my case, I'm very pleased.
Total compensation can be in average 25% higher in a top hedge fund, but base on my experience, the culture and commitment to technology investment at MS are very hard to match.

review_title: Laid back employers with positive attitudes.
pros: The brokers that I work for are always kind even under stress and everyone at the firm seems genuinely kind. There are a lot of programs within the company to build your professional career and the firm pays for its employees to receive special licenses. If you want a specific license for your job title, they pay for your study materials, your test, and compensate you when you pass the test and receive the title. They genuinely want to see their employees further their professional career.
cons: The position is not for those that want an 8-4 or 9-5 job everyday. Some days you can count on being in the office for 8 hours but sometimes, especially during the quarter end, expect to not know when you will finish up the work day. The work load is to be expected during the quarter/month end, but during the month you could have a lot to do or not a whole lot to do, it depends on many different factors.

review_title: Decent hours but not a long term career destination
job_title: Vice President Fixed Income in New York, NY
pros:
You work with a few smart and driven ppl in some areas.
Work life balance is relatively better and benefits are not too bad. 3 yr 401k vesting with 4% match and health care and family benefits decent
cons:
At the top levels you see a clear pattern of non diversity. They have few females but mainly for window dressing.
This is an equity shop and won't get paid in any other division.
If you are not in front office, your compensation will stagnate each year irrespective of firm performance
Most functions are very siloed for cost reasons and cross department or function learning non existent
Internal mobility is not easy as they say

job_title: Senior Java Developer/NY in New York, NY
pros: The badge -- you are at Morgan Stanley.  If you like to be around younger people -- this is like high school, age-wise.
cons: The management is addicted to docile Indian laborers.  Management is dis-interested in your strengths or your career development.  Their ideal employee is a robotic creature devoid of any interests,  fast, doesn't have any new ideas, doesn't ask any questions.   Management is not secure or very competent and actively competes with sub-ordinates.    Management is addicted to their personal cult which comes easy with Indian laborers but is weird for the few Americans that are hired.   You didn't go to college for this  -  steer clear.

pros: Morgan Stanley has pretty great name recognition so it will look good on your resume for future employers.  The people you work with are usually helpful and the benefits are good.
cons:
1.  For a multinational powerhouse, they have the absolute worst obsolete technology imaginable.  We're talking early 90's at best.  Almost nothing is automated and the functions that are automated don't work half the time.  If your clients want to transfer money online, just tell them to stick with their bank because they probably won't be able to do it here for another 10 years.  

2.  Very little support for new financial advisors.   It's very difficult to get a straight answer on anything.

3.  Very complex fee structure for clients that constantly changes.  

4.  Overly strict company policies make it very difficult to provide the level of service that clients deserve.

pros: Great benefits, opportunities to grow within, supportive management in some offices (all offices are a different), they believe in everyone holding integrity, respect for each other in all ways. Management tries to be supportive with financial advisors new to the industry.
cons:
lower pay (if salary employee). Financial Advisor positions are 90% failure rate coming in new to industry. Most won't try to get to know you until you have been their a while. The seasoned advisors are not open to bringing in partners like management wants them to, so new FA's be warned. 
Lots of hours marketing, calling, networking to build your business if new. That never ends as you must always bring in new clients to keep your business growing.

review_title: Sinking or swimming in the Bering Sea
pros: There is a lot of flexibilty in how you build your business.  It's up to you - sink or swim.  If you love talking to people, don't have fear of rejection, and are well connected you can make a lot of money.  Pure capitalism at its "finest."  Brand name provides a marginal benefit when speaking with clients/prospects
cons: Salary is very low versus other careers, and sales pressure is heavy and persistent.  It's nearly impossible to reach the goals that are presented in your job offer because industry fees continue to compress, payouts are slim for newcomers, and clients and potential clients generally consider what you do to be a commodity.  Very few truly prosper.  Don't expect to make a whole lot for at least 4 years unless you have rich family members willing to let you manage their cash.

review_title: Great at first-downhill after two years.
pros: Management is pretty open about market changes and the direction of the business. For example, three years ago ahead of the Volker Rule, the former CEO, John Mack, said that he was re-engineering the firm to be less principal activity driven, and more client-focused/flow focused.
cons:
Outside of investment banking and a few algo prop traders still leftover, pay typically is between 25 to 75% less than street standard for anyone VP and below. 

Part of the problem is the review process. For non-officers, there is only one person who reviews you- your boss. You could get rated "Above Expectations" yet get paid the worst quartile in year end bonus. There is no logic to how comp is determined if indeed there is supposed to be a correlation with performance.

The recent rounds of layoffs were all communicated to the media prior to the employees. Classy.

review_title: Great company, but really depends on team and area
pros:
Working with nice and smart people, generally speaking. 
Focus on internal mobility, making it easier to take advantage of opportunities to move to different departments or offices across the globe (I worked in NY and Hong Kong)
cons:
Its finance, hours can be tough.
Heavily dependent on the market, layoffs are pretty common
Every team/department/division has its own culture, so people can have vast experiences

job_title: Client Service Representative in Baltimore, MD
pros: First and foremost Morgan Stanley is a great name. It is a good company to have on your resume. Also, the benefits are great and on top of that you get 20 days of vacation. The offices in New York are very nice and for some of the new hires in the Baltimore area they pay for you to train in NY for a few weeks.
cons: At Morgan Stanley you will work long hours and there is no hour lunch, you simply run to get food and then eat at your desk. This often leads to burn out among the employees and moral goes down quickly. There is no overtime and when the technology doesn't work you have to sit there for hours just waiting. There were some days when I was there until 10pm at night for reasons I could not control. Also, the Baltimore office lacks leadership, most of the management there are new and don't have experience within Morgan Stanley.

pros:
It pays reasonably well.
There is good work/life balance, although I think the real reason behind this is that management is too oblivious to care what your doing, hence it is easy to balance non-work obligations with work.
The benefits package is not bad
cons:
Advancement is based on age. If you are near 50, promotion and advancement are highly unlikely. Over 50 there is no advancement except in the most senior ranks.
Management decisions are based on a given manager's bonus calculation--e.g., you will not be rewarded for innovation, intelligence, or even a job well done if it contradicts the politics that impact the manager's bonus calculation.
Innovation, intelligence, good work in and of themselves are not the primary factor in advancement--see last point

job_title: Software Development Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Overall this is a very good company to work for. Some of the highlights are:

 -  Morgan Stanley is full of very talented and smart people
 -  Morgan Stnaley uses a broad technology spectrum and experiments with lots of cutting edge technology
 -  The benefits are generally very good. (e.g. up to 3 months of paid family leave under certain circumstances, such as having a baby)
 -  Most departments operate on very high ethical standards
 -  Good training program
 -  Compensation is generally very good
cons:
Morgan Stanley is a large and some times anonymous corporation. As a result the departments can be very fragmented (eg. if you want to run a database you have to go through the dba group)

My biggest gripe is that Morgan Stanley engages in extensive offshoring, especially to India, which can be a challenge and dampens morale for NY-based employees.

pros: Work with great people. Lots of really bright colleagues in the Baltimore and New York offices. Mobility after a certain period of you being a full time employee. Looks excellent on a resume for another job. Gives you tons of experience as most groups do a little bit of everything along with their full day to day job. If you are able to make the jump and advance on to NY(main office), it's a company to look at.
cons: Underpaid. Something you'll hear most about working in operations but even more so at Morgan Stanley. They are constantly looking for ways to cut costs and one way is pay people less. Lots of turnover so there are always issues with keeping experience high and knowing the full range of what each group does.

review_title: Generally nice people to work with but compensation and career progress let's them down.
pros: Friendly people, most teams have an open door policy, very multicultural teams and respect for diversity. Work life balance is good. Flexible work arrangements are generally the norm. Onsite gym is ok value for money and convenient.
cons: Long term staff retention is poor. Overall structure of pay and compensation is poor compared to other firms. Use "titles" to promote rather than fair compensation for the right level. Too many levels which are not really useful such as manager vs senior manager. Promotion to VP/officer level near impossible in some departments, takes too long and little or no increase in salary when & if it happens. Short term view on cost cutting means they don't invest in people long term and the result is high turnover, and bad morale.

review_title: Stable job, a bit boring though.
pros: Since all groups across the firm are different, I'll stick to personal experience. IT infrastructure is one of the best among several financial companies I had a chance working with. Middle management is flexible and encourages innovations and new ideas. Professional training courses available and staff encouraged to regularly enroll. 4 weeks vacation and work/life balance are good benefits hardly matched outside of financial sector.
cons: Again, personal experience only, do not extrapolate. No promotions or salary raises in years. Bonus has been cut lately due to overall economy situation. Problems to solve are not challenging enough which is quite boring. As usual within financial sector there are many limitations to personal 401K fund allocations. Overall job at financial institution is not sexy enough in comparison with hot startups.

review_title: Good work life balance, pay below standard.
job_title: Technology Associate in New York, NY
pros: Good work life balance if you're in a back office IT position. IT infrastructure is first class. Hours are normal 9-6'ish in my team. Good amount of support from peers. If you're at Morgan Stanley, join the "hackers" mail group, it will make the days go by faster.
cons: Turn over is high, the bank is top heavy with lots of VPs and EDs because pay is always below par. They tend to give titles bumps to associates because it's cheaper than giving salary increases. Bonuses are lackluster as well in a back office position... Less than 5% for most of the people i spoke with. A lot of associates and VPs are leaving because of the pay. Lots of H1-B and contractors to suppress the pay scale

job_title: Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Company has a good reputation, focus on diversity, good maternity/paternity leave benefits. Depending on the position, the employee gets 2 weeks vacation time, plus another consecutive 2 weeks vacation during the year. That is separate from sick time. Senior leadership individuals visit various offices throughout the year, which I find impressive.  Good culture and values - they place priority on volunteering and giving back to the community.
cons: It is hard to advance within the company from what I have seen, both in position and salary. There seems to be a certain amount of favoritism. Raises each year appear to be below the average percentage, which is discouraging. I find it has been difficult to trust management. Workload isn't divided equally throughout the team, some people work harder than others, but are treated the same as those that do the bare minimum.

review_title: I am not gonna leave the company if given an option
pros:
Best company to work for married women, great culture, good pay, work life balance, proper management and what not... 
Its been more than a year I am working here and I must say this is kind of dream company where you get the feel of proper corporate environment, you are getting good money  for your work, able to manage your work life balance, having one of the best leave policy across industry (more than 30sick leaves are allowed). 
Yes u have to be very careful with your work as this company ask for the quality.. error can cost you much. 
 
I am working in Mumbai office.
cons: Job security- as it's an MNC,  I am not sure about job security though it's s depends on accuracy of your work and availability of manpower too.

review_title: Used to have a very solid reputation...now that is in question
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Many challenging projects and opportunities.  Exciting work; very skilled and respected colleagues from the best schools.  Collaborative culture among the "working class."
cons: Very political.  Need to be aligned with the group in power to advance.  There is real trouble in the Fixed Income division.  It is causing a huge negative impact on the Firm.  Rumors of more planned lay offs in early 2016.  People work in fear for being in the next wave of reductions. The current CEO(Gorman) is set for a few more years here and that forced the former president (Fleming) to resign.  Both actions are of concern.

pros: Well recognized brand, strong investment platforms that allow you to utilize outside money managers, mutual funds and ETF's that are priced at competitive level. Strong Institutional devision with Graystone Consulting, that allows financial advisors the ability to select Graystone Consultants that are knowledgable in the $20-$500 institutional space.
cons: Company is not run by people that came from the wealth management.  Client experience is not as important to Morgan Stanley as it was in the Smith Barney environment.  Managers decision making capabilities in centralized and they branch managers have to manage up.  The firm has decided to build its own CRM and performance report which has been very challenging and costly.

review_title: Your Advancement Is Up to You
job_title: Senior Associate in New York, NY
pros: The firm is truly world-class and comprises the best and brightest talent in the industry.  There are many skilled professionals who are ready, willing, and able to assist you in your career advancement goals.  If you are aggressive, outgoing, and optimistic, you can get to know people and get yourself involved in noteworthy projects and initiatives.  The benefits are also top notch - medical, dental, vision, 401(K), pension, etc...
cons: The firm is very large so you can easily get lost in the rank and file.  In addition to focusing on your work, you must make an effort to network internally and get to know people in senior management.  Also, the firm is prone to volatile ups and downs due to being in the financial services industry.  Therefore, the chances of being laid off are ever present.

review_title: Work Life Balance varies on position, mgr and projects.
job_title: IBD IT in New York, NY
pros:
Great benefits.
Tons of vacation.
Looks good on your resume.
Ability to work from home.
cons:
When you support investment bankers you work banker hours. So that would be ALL the time. Weekends? Evenings? If you are building software expect to be on high alert if you're not working. 

Ridiculous amounts of meetings. Layers and layers of approvals to move at the speed of molasses.

Also, an eye boggling number of employees exist (and are promoted) due to how they speak of their work. Meaning, they're not actually doing the work. If you end up working here remember to nod and smile. (You'll be shocked at how behind some of the technology is. Also going along with the program is important. It will impact your compensation if you're deemed too )

review_title: Highly political, employees are seen in dollar not human terms
pros: Still employs highly intelligent and motivated people.  The highly complex, global environment and fast pace offer challenges and learning experiences unavailable in smaller domestic companies.
cons: Simply put, you're asked to give more than you get.  You'll need to work long hours and weekends.  Your personal life and academic interests will have to take a subordinate position to the firm's current agenda.  Politics rather than results are rewarded.  Innovation, dedication, and results are not valued beyond rhetoric.

pros: Salary is very competitive, Technology is up-to-date and people are generally nice (depending on the team you fall in with).  Able to work remotely in urgent situations or if sick.  A lot of room for advancement and very supportive of continuing education and tuition reimbursement.  My manager was very understanding if I had to leave for a class or training session.
cons: Typical banking-egos.  A lot of implied sexism.  Still very much a "boys club". It's a dog-eat-dog industry, so that's to be expected.  Some fairly unethical behavior that subordinates are expected to ignore.  Too much money spent on lavish dinners and events and not enough on employees.  Work-life-balance is encouraged but in reality, you are expected to be attached to your blackberry and laptop 24/7

pros: Good company brand. Not sure why most of the employees are based in NYC except the ones in Purchase. Those Purchase employees are considered a tax write off casualties because many of them commute. It's a horrible commute if you encounter traffic from CT, NYC or NJ. Good people who work for the company and want to see the firm thrive.
cons: Morgan Stanley loves to give praises but not raises. If you get promoted, don't expect an increase. A lot of good talent has left the company because outside firms actually pay. The way the company makes money off of their margins, the company will lose a lot of good people and have to retrain other ones in a short span if at all. Many people resign as well because senior management has wanted to relocate certain locations. Why don't we uproot senior management and see if they like it?

review_title: Can't ride on its name forever
pros: Morgan Stanley is a great company and has many dedicated, hard working and highly professional staff.
cons: There has been a chronic lack of investment in systems and processes. I work at MSIM and the amount of manual number crunching is frightening. Lots of not-very-well-thought out outsourcing which is so obviously down to penny pinching. I find immediate management are passive when dealing with more senior management and quite aggressive when dealing with direct reports and those lower down the food chain and quite eager to stab anyone perceived as a threat in the back. Pay is also not great and long hours are needed to get through the workload as teams are under-resourced.

pros:

review_title: Terrible experience, if I could rate zero stars I would do so.
job_title: Senior Client Service Associate in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Cannot honestly think of anything positive to say about this company, sorry

review_title: Cares too much about the bottom line to be a competitive employer.
job_title: Operations Associate in South Jordan, UT
pros: Employer annual match contributions to your 401k are excellent, which should be expected of a brokerage firm. Growth in my retirement savings has been more aggressive than with other employers in the past.
cons: The average employee never sees anything of an annual bonus, not even around the holidays. Operations is seen as gruntwork and viewed as a liability more than as an asset. pros: Job security, great co-workers and very good benefits and perks. Technology was constantly growing while I was there and that is always a positive when you work at a financial institution.
cons: Low salary, constant cost cutting and no clear path for job trajectory. I felt that there wasn't enough of a difference in compensation between the best employees and the worst employees.

job_title: Executive Director, Technology in Hong Kong
pros:
The culture here is great. People help each other. The people I work with and manage are very talented. The company offers very good training opportunities. The projects are also very interesting and provide an opportunity to serve customers at one of the best Wall Street companies.

Management is generally open to comment and usually resolves issues (see also cons below).

Good place for working parents. But the lack of a daycare center at the workplace makes it difficult to return from parenting leave.
cons:
Sometimes it feels the environment is too fast paced to make strategic investments in systems. As with any big firm, it sometimes feels too slow to embrace change.

Work life balance could also be better out here in Asia. Though in theory, everyone gets the flexibility to come in late when they take late calls, but it is rarely a good alternative. Evening time with family can be irreplaceable.

An alternative to neglecting late calls is to lose your career growth options.

review_title: Great People, Interesting Work, Slow Advancement
job_title: Vice President, Senior Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: I was paid a competitive salary and for the most part I really liked the people with whom I worked with the exception of my managers. With only a couple of exceptions over my 16 year career there, I consistently had poor managers who rarely had my back and seemed to be out for themselves. There was no meaningful feedback, no spirit of collaboration or team. But the company treated me well and I generally looked forward to going to work.
cons: As noted in my Pros, I generally lacked trust in my immediate managers, they largely seemed to be looking out for themselves and not enabling or empowering their teams. It was also hard to advance and get promoted as it required advocacy of your direct manager. Seemed to be more a popularity contest than merit-based.

review_title: Good luck, but you probably won't make it.

pros: Very professional environment. Well-respected, well-known name. It was great to tell people I worked for Morgan Stanley, my credibility went up. Good training salary!

And, maybe I wasn't suited to the business. But, I was unimpressed!

review_title: Can be a good place to work

review_title: Morgan Stanley Great Place to Work, but Risky and Time Consuming
pros: At Morgan Stanley, I enjoy a great salary and fantastic benefits.  I also feel great knowing that I work with some of the smartest people in the industry.  My coworkers are all outstanding.  My job is incredibly fast paced, so there's little room for time to get bored.
cons: The downside of working for any large company like Morgan Stanley is that there are lots of politics involved -- it varies significantly by manager, but many managers do not value work-life balance and there are often people who get rewarded for doing very little work.  But you can find that anywhere.  The most significant downside is that the market is very volatile and your job is at the mercy of the market.
